dcterms:title: Multiomics of Bohring-Opitz syndrome truncating ASXL1 mutations identify canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling dysregulation
dcterms:abstract: ASXL1 (additional sex combsâ€“like 1) plays key roles in epigenetic regulation of early developmental gene expression. De novo protein-truncating mutations in ASXL1 cause Bohring-Opitz syndrome (BOS; OMIM #605039), a rare neurodevelopmental condition characterized by severe intellectual disabilities, distinctive facial features, hypertrichosis, increased risk of Wilms tumor, and variable congenital anomalies, including heart defects and severe skeletal defects giving rise to a typical BOS posture. These BOS-causing ASXL1 variants are also high-prevalence somatic driver mutations in acute myeloid leukemia. We used primary cells from individuals with BOS (n = 18) and controls (n = 49) to dissect gene regulatory changes caused by ASXL1 mutations using comprehensive multiomics assays for chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq), DNA methylation, histone methylation binding, and transcriptome in peripheral blood and skin fibroblasts. Our data show that regardless of cell type, ASXL1 mutations drive strong cross-tissue effects that disrupt multiple layers of the epigenome. The data showed a broad activation of canonical Wnt signaling at the transcriptional and protein levels and upregulation of VANGL2, which encodes a planar cell polarity pathway protein that acts through noncanonical Wnt signaling to direct tissue patterning and cell migration. This multiomics approach identifies the core impact of ASXL1 mutations and therapeutic targets for BOS and myeloid leukemias.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Gene regulatory changes data from multiomics assays including chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq), DNA methylation, histone methylation binding, and transcriptome analyses

obi:RO_0002211.dcterms:description: The paper shows that ASXL1 mutations affect neuron projection development which regulates neural crest development, particularly during early morphogenesis

obi:RO_0002629.dcterms:description: The study demonstrates that canonical Wnt signaling positively regulates cell differentiation processes in development, particularly in stem cell maintenance

obi:RO_0002211.dcterms:description: The research shows that planar cell polarity signaling regulates cell migration and tissue patterning during development
The paper demonstrates that histone modifications regulate gene expression through epigenetic mechanisms

obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:description: The study shows that beta-catenin signaling occurs in the nucleus where it activates target gene expression

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: The research indicates that neural tube formation is part of nervous system development, affected by VANGL2 regulation
The paper shows that cardiac development is part of embryonic development, affected by ASXL1 mutations

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Bohring-Opitz syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Caused by truncating mutations in ASXL1 gene characterized by severe intellectual disabilities, distinctive facial features, hypertrichosis, increased risk of Wilms tumor, and heart defects. Study found that ASXL1 mutations drive activation of canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling pathways, particularly affecting neural development and body patterning. Mutations lead to epigenetic dysregulation affecting multiple tissue types.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: acute myeloid leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: ASXL1 truncating mutations serve as somatic driver mutations in this cancer. The same mutations that cause Bohring-Opitz syndrome are found as high-prevalence mutations in acute myeloid leukemia, affecting stem cell identity and differentiation.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: myelodysplastic syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: ASXL1 truncating mutations are found in approximately 16% of cases, affecting myeloid differentiation through epigenetic dysregulation.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: craniorachischisis
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Severe neural tube defect linked to VANGL2 mutations, which is dysregulated in Bohring-Opitz syndrome. Homozygous mutations are embryonic lethal in humans.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: histone H3
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: ASXL1 mutations affect histone H3 modifications, particularly H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 levels, impacting gene regulation

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: glutamate
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Glutamate receptor genes like GRIK5 show increased expression in BOS patients with ASXL1 mutations

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: ubiquitin
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: ASXL1 mutations affect H2AK119 deubiquitination processes and ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation pathways

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: DNA
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: DNA methylation patterns are altered in BOS patients, with significant changes in CpG methylation affecting gene expression

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Vincristine
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Vincristine was administered with actinomycin D for Wilms tumor treatment in one patient (Pt6) before sample collection. Following this treatment, the patient's blood RNA-seq showed complete loss of heterozygosity with all reads containing the pathogenic ASXL1 mutation.

obi:OBI_0000968.dcterms:description: ATAC-seq, CUT&RUN, Illumina Epic Arrays, RNA-seq

obi:OBI_0000293.dcterms:description: Primary cells from individuals with BOS (n = 18) and controls (n = 49), including peripheral blood and skin fibroblasts

obi:OBI_0200000.dcterms:description: Multiomics analysis of chromatin accessibility, DNA methylation, histone methylation binding, and transcriptome data

obi:OBI_0000251.dcterms:description: 18 individuals with BOS, 25 sex-matched and genetically related controls, and 30 sex- and age-matched controls were recruited

obi:OBI_0000070.dcterms:description: ATAC-seq for chromatin accessibility, CUT&RUN for H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 enrichment, DNA methylation analysis through Illumina Epic Arrays, and RNA-seq for transcriptome analysis

obi:IAO_0000616.dcterms:description: The authors have declared that no conflict of interest exists.

cito:cites.dcterms:title: A human homolog of Additional sex combs, ADDITIONAL SEX COMBS-LIKE 1, maps to chromosome 20q11
The HARE-HTH and associated domains novel modules in the coordination of epigenetic DNA and protein modifications
Functional proteomics of the epigenetic regulators ASXL1, ASXL2 and ASXL3 a convergence of proteomics and epigenetics for translational medicine
Characterization of the plant homeodomain (PHD) reader family for their histone tail interactions
The PHD finger a versatile epigenome reader
Genome regulation by polycomb and trithorax 70 years and counting

dcterms:hasPart: A research paper titled Multiomics of Bohring-Opitz syndrome truncating ASXL1 mutations identify canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling dysregulation was published in JCI Insight on April 13 2023 by Isabella Lin Angela Wei Zain Awamleh Meghna Singh Aileen Ning Analeyla Herrera Bianca E Russell Rosanna Weksberg and Valerie A Arboleda The study investigated how ASXL1 mutations affect gene regulation in Bohring-Opitz syndrome BOS using multiomics approaches The research analyzed primary cells from 18 BOS patients and 49 controls examining chromatin accessibility DNA methylation histone methylation binding and transcriptome in blood and skin fibroblasts ASXL1 plays key roles in epigenetic regulation of early developmental gene expression and mutations cause severe intellectual disabilities distinctive facial features hypertrichosis increased Wilms tumor risk and congenital anomalies The study found that ASXL1 mutations drive strong cross tissue effects disrupting multiple epigenome layers and activating canonical Wnt signaling The research revealed that neuron projection development regulates neural crest development during early morphogenesis Canonical Wnt signaling positively regulates cell differentiation processes particularly in stem cell maintenance Planar cell polarity signaling through VANGL2 regulates cell migration and tissue patterning Histone modifications regulate gene expression through epigenetic mechanisms with beta catenin signaling occurring in the nucleus Neural tube formation part of nervous system development is affected by VANGL2 regulation and cardiac development is impacted by ASXL1 mutations The same ASXL1 mutations are found in acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome affecting stem cell identity and differentiation The study showed alterations in histone H3 modifications particularly H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 levels increased expression of glutamate receptor genes like GRIK5 changes in H2AK119 deubiquitination processes and DNA methylation patterns The research utilized ATAC seq CUT and RUN Illumina Epic Arrays and RNA seq for comprehensive analysis of epigenetic and transcriptional changes One patient received vincristine and actinomycin D treatment for Wilms tumor showing complete loss of heterozygosity with all reads containing the pathogenic ASXL1 mutation This multiomics approach identifies core impacts of ASXL1 mutations and potential therapeutic targets for both BOS and myeloid leukemias
